title: Stock Futures Rise Ahead of Earnings; Tesla and IBM are scheduled to post results after Wednesday's close
text:
Stocks have been boosted in recent days, driven by better-than-expected quarterly results from large U.S. banks.

"The numbers coming through on the earnings are more positive than expectations. That's giving a short term momentum," said Niall O'Sullivan, chief investment officer of multiasset strategies at Neuberger Berman.

"But actions you would expect to see in the early stages of a recession are being taken" such as hiring freezes, "which maybe speak to a more challenging environment coming," Mr. O'Sullivan said.

In premarket trading, Netflix jumped more than 14% after it said it gained 2.4 million new subscribers last quarter, more than double the level it was expecting. United Airlines rose 7% after it said demand for air travel is resilient and that it expects a profit margin to rise beyond prepandemic levels by the end of the year.

Companies including consumer-goods giant Procter & Gamble, insurer Travelers Companies and pharmaceutical firm Abbott Laboratories are scheduled to report earnings ahead of the opening bell. Reports from Tesla and IBM are expected after markets close.

Markets calming in the U.K. after a period of high volatility also contributed to broader sentiment. The Bank of England's recent bond-market intervention was taken as a sign that central banks can still act to stabilize markets in times of crisis, despite high inflation, investors said.

Data on the housing market are set to go out at 8:30 a.m. ET, with housing starts expected to have declined in September from the prior month.

Oil prices edged up, with global crude benchmark Brent climbing 0.9% to trade at $90.85 a barrel. Traders are weighing the potential impact of the Biden administration planning to sell more oil from strategic reserves with the aim of lowering prices.

The yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note edged up to 4.065% from 3.996% the day before. Yields and prices move in opposite directions.

Overseas, the pan-continental Stoxx Europe 600 added 0.2%. Dutch semiconductor firm ASML Holding climbed 8% after reporting a narrower drop in profit last quarter, driven by record bookings.

In Asia, most major benchmarks retreated. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.2% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index declined 2.4%.

Write to Anna Hirtenstein at anna.hirtenstein@wsj.com

Stock Futures Rise Ahead of Earnings
